title: Slack

content:

Check daily for messages that you haven't reacted / responded to in Mentions & reactions.
Proactively react to other people's messages.

title: Slack
content:
Share information for the benefit of others.
Send a message when starting a task.
Send a message including your thoughts when finishing a task.

title: Our Team Policy
content:
Our goal is to grow and strengthen as a team.
We aim to partake in enjoyable team-building activities.
We pledge to act with the best interests of the team and ourselves in mind.
heading: Teamwork

title: Our Team Policy
content:
We are committed to honoring project deadlines.
We strive to deliver work of the highest quality.
heading: Deadline Adherence and Quality Assurance

title: Our Team Policy
content:
We encourage proposing new project ideas.
We advocate for active contribution of suggestions.
We will foster an environment that promotes continuous improvement.
heading: Innovative Suggestions

title: Our Team Policy
content:
We are dedicated to pursuing personal growth and lifelong learning.
We are committed to contributing to the growth of our team and its members.
heading: Personal and Team Growth

title: Our Team Policy
content:
We will adhere to the guidelines set out in the Documentation for all projects.
If application of the guidelines is difficult, unclear, or a more efficient solution is available, we will consult the administrator.
We will acknowledge that we have reviewed the Documentation by providing a response.
Each project lead will confirm when they have fully implemented the guidelines from the Documentation.
heading: Documentation Compliance

title: Our Team Policy
content:
In terms of business etiquette, we will:

Initiate greetings in a proactive and cheerful manner.
Maintain clear eye contact when greeting others.
heading: Business Etiquette

title: Our Team Policy
content:
We are responsible for tidying up after ourselves.
We will maintain the cleanliness and organization of shared spaces.
heading: Workplace Cleanliness

title: Git User Profiles
content: This document will guide you on setting up your git user profiles using the Git Config User Profiles extension in VSCode. This is especially helpful for people who share a development device.

title: Git User Profiles
content:
Navigate to the Extensions tab.
Search for Git Config User Profiles and install it.
heading: Installing the Extension

title: Git User Profiles
content:
Open the command palette with Shift + Command + P.
Search and execute git config user profiles: create a git config user profile.
You will then be prompted to enter your profile name, account name, and an email address to create your profile.
heading: Creating a Git Config User Profile

title: Git User Profiles
content:
Open the command palette again.
Search and execute Git Config User Profiles: Select a git config user profile.
A confirmation pop-up will appear in the bottom right corner. If there are no issues, proceed with the selection.

Note: This operation will update the account information documented in the open project to the selected profile.
heading: Selecting a Git Config User Profile

title: Git User Profiles
content:
If there are discrepancies between the account information in the selected profile and the open file, a warning will be displayed in yellow on the blue bar at the bottom of the screen. To resolve this:

Click on the warning or,
Repeat step [3] of the Selecting a Git Config User Profile section above to select the correct profile.

View this guide on GitHub >
heading: Resolving Account Information Discrepancies

title: Git User Profiles
content: Creating a Git Config User Profile
heading: Creating a Git Config User Profile

title: Git User Profiles
content: Selecting a Git Config User Profile
heading: Selecting a Git Config User Profile

title: GitHub Actions
content: We use GitHub Actions to perform two types of CI: Checks and tests.

title: GitHub Actions
content:
Run a lint check, a type check, and Svelte check.

jobs:
  check:
    name: Check
    runs-on: ubuntu-latest
    steps:
      name: Lint Check
        run: npm run lint

      name: Type Check
        run: npm run typecheck

      name: Svelte Check
        run: npm run check
heading: Checks

title: GitHub Actions
content:
Execute tests using Vitest and Playwright.

jobs:
  tests:
    name: Tests
    runs-on: ubuntu-latest
    steps:
      name: Vitest Test
        run: npm run test:ci

      name: Playwright Test
        run: npm run test:e2e
heading: Tests

title: GitHub Actions
content:
Output Playwright Report and logs.

jobs:
  tests:
    name: Tests
    runs-on: ubuntu-latest
    steps:
      uses: actions/upload-artifact@v3
        if: always()
        with:
          name: playwright-report
          path: playwright-report/
          retention-days: 30

      uses: actions/upload-artifact@v3
        if: always()
        with:
          name: logs
          path: logs/
          retention-days: 30
heading: Output

title: Git Hooks
content:
We use lint-staged and Husky for our Git Hooks.

lint-staged - Run linters against staged git files and don't let üí© slip into your code base!
Husky - Husky improves your commits and more üê∂ woof!

title: Git Hooks
heading: lint-staged

title: Git Hooks
content:
Combine ESLint, Prettier, and lint-staged to format code.

#!/bin/sh
. "$(dirname "$0")/_/husky.sh"

npx lint-staged

npm run lint
heading: pre-commit

title: Git Hooks
content:
Perform TypeScript type checking, run tests with Vitest, and finally check for conflicts.

{
	"scripts": {
		"test:run": "vitest run",
		"test:e2e": "playwright test",
		"check": "svelte-kit sync && svelte-check --tsconfig ./tsconfig.json",
		"typecheck": "tsc --noEmit"
	}
}

#!/bin/sh
. "$(dirname "$0")/_/husky.sh"

npm run typecheck
npm run check

npm run test:run
npm run test:e2e

npm run build

git fetch origin
git merge --no-commit --no-ff origin/main
git reset --hard HEAD
heading: pre-push

Playwright is an E2E (end-to-end) testing framework.

Getting started with writing end-to-end tests with Playwright:
Initializing project in '.'
‚úî Where to put your end-to-end tests? ¬∑ e2e
‚úî Add a GitHub Actions workflow? (y/N) ¬∑ N
‚úî Install Playwright browsers (can be done manually via 'npx playwright install')? (Y/n) ¬∑ Y

 on_click_button(text)} />

title: TypeScript Config
content: How we modify our TypeScript code style with tsconfig.json.

title: TypeScript Config
content:
Set strict to true, and further increase strictness by modifying the following options:

allowUnreachableCode
exactOptionalPropertyTypes
noImplicitOverride
noImplicitReturns
noFallthroughCasesInSwitch

{
	"extends": "./.svelte-kit/tsconfig.json",
	"compilerOptions": {
		"strict": true,

		"allowUnreachableCode": false,
		"exactOptionalPropertyTypes": true,
		"noImplicitOverride": true,
		"noImplicitReturns": true,
		"noFallthroughCasesInSwitch": true
		// "noUncheckedIndexedAccess": true,
	}
}
heading: TSConfig

title: Customize Zsh
content:
Oh My Zsh is a delightful, open source, community-driven framework for managing your Zsh configuration. It comes bundled with thousands of helpful functions, helpers, plugins, themes, and a few things that make you shout... More Info >

sh -c "$(curl -fsSL https://raw.githubusercontent.com/ohmyzsh/ohmyzsh/master/tools/install.sh)"
heading: oh-my-zsh

title: Customize Zsh
content:
Additional completion definitions for Zsh. More Info >

brew install zsh-completions

To activate these completions, add the following to your .zshrc:

if type brew &>/dev/null; then
	FPATH=$(brew --prefix)/share/zsh-completions:$FPATH

	autoload -Uz compinit
	compinit
fi
heading: zsh-completions

title: Customize Zsh
content:
It suggests commands as you type based on history and completions. More Info >

brew install zsh-autosuggestions

To activate the autosuggestions, add the following at the end of your .zshrc:

source /opt/homebrew/share/zsh-autosuggestions/zsh-autosuggestions.zsh
heading: zsh-autosuggestions

title: Customize Zsh
content:
Fish shell-like syntax highlighting for Zsh. More Info >

brew install zsh-syntax-highlighting

you may need to add the following to your .zshenv:

export ZSH_HIGHLIGHT_HIGHLIGHTERS_DIR=/opt/homebrew/share/zsh-syntax-highlighting/highlighters
heading: zsh-syntax-highlighting

heading: Apps

title: App Structure
content:
This app consists the following screens:

Talk
Translate
Chat
Docs

title: App Structure
content:
On the Talk screen, you can select sentences and listen to how they are pronounced.

After listening, you can check your own pronunciation through the app.

You can also register new sentences and add new translations.
heading: Talk

title: App Structure
content:
On the Translate screen, people can have spoken conversations with other people who speak different languages.

When you speak, your words will be displayed in the other party's language and you will hear their words in your own language.

This service allows you to converse in your own language and have a conversation with someone who speaks a different language.
heading: Translate

title: App Structure
content:
On the Chat screen, people can converse through text online with people who speak different languages.

Each user sends messages in their native language, and if the participants speak different languages, their messages will be automatically translated.

Additionally, when a participating member speaks in a different language, their message will be translated into the receiver's language.
heading: Chat

title: App Structure
content:
We have the following documentation pages available:

Getting Started - Introduction and usage guide for this app.
Development - An introduction to development methods for our services.
Our Concepts - An explanation of our development concepts.
heading: Docs

title: Creating a Project
content:
MySQL Community Server 8.0.30 or higher
Node.js 18.4.0 or higher
npm 8.13.2 or higher
heading: Prerequisites

title: Creating a Project
content:
Here are the steps:

Get the project and setup:

Clone the repo to your current directory
git clone https://github.com/sinProject-Inc/talk.git

Install the dependencies
cd /talk
npm install

Create a database with the name "talk"
Create a .env file by copying .env.example at the top level of the project
Rewrite the .env file with your environment variables
Push the initial schema and data to the database:

npx prisma db push
npx prisma generate
npx prisma db seed

Install Redis, and run the command: redis-server
Run locally

Start the server and open the app in a new browser tab
npm run dev -- --open
heading: Setting up the project

title: Introduction
content:
An email address is required to use the service.
If you're reading this document to learn Svelte or SvelteKit, try the Svelte tutorial first.
If you get stuck, ask for help at @iam_o_sin on Twitter.
heading: Before we begin

title: Introduction
content: Talk is an app for conversing in real time with people who speak different languages. You can learn languages in addition to also having conversations through both voice and text.
heading: What is Talk?

title: Introduction
content: sinProject Inc. is an software development company in Osaka, Japan. We primarily use SvelteKit and TypeScript, but also work with other programming languages and frameworks.
heading: What is sinProject?

title: Introduction
content:
Talk was created to establish coding conventions and development policies at sinProject Inc.

This guide covers various topics, such as how to use TypeScript, coding styles, GitHub workflows, defining GitHub Actions, login procedures, handling external APIs, and more. It serves as a comprehensive guideline for product development at sinProject.
heading: What does Talk offer sinProject?
